description.narrative: Across Africa and Latin America, small and growing businesses (SGBs) are trapped in the missing middle, the gap between microfinance and commercial bank financing. This gap is particularly pronounced in the agricultural sector, where businesses often struggle to access credit from local banks due to a lack of formal collateral, geographic isolation, perceptions of risk , and limited managerial capacity. As a result, agricultural businesses fail to grow and to realize their potential to improve farmer livelihoods and strengthen domestic and regional food security. This intervention will directly affect small farmers, foremost in Africa, and be benififical for them by helping them grow their business. By this contribution Sida will support the expansion of local currency lending. The Sida grant will be matched by a commercial loan which then, as a development loan, will function as a reserve for adverse currency fluctuations in local currency lending.

Insatsen är ett stöd till Root Capital (Amerikansk Non profit Foundation/NGO) i form av ett utvecklingslån, som är en kombination av ett lån från externt finansinstitut och en gåva från Sida. I denna insats är New Island Capital den partnern som ska ge ut lånet som ska kombineras med ett bidrag från Sida. Genom insatsen kommer Root Capital att kunna öka sin utlåning i lokal valuta samt minska sin valuta risk vid utlåning till småskaligt jordbruk i Afrikanska valutor som omsätts mindre på valutamarknaden. Root Capital har sin inlåning i USD och utlåning i dessa valutor. Det är dyrt och svårt att säkra valutarisker för mindre belopp, en kostnad som i förlängningen riskerar att påverka lånekostnaden för jordbrukaren.Valutarisken delas mellan Sida och New Island Capital genom att ett särskilt konto sätts upp för att parerara framtida negativa valutakursrörelser.Insatsen ska fungera som ett skydd mot extrema lokala valutakursfluktuationer. Genom att tydligt avtala om hur och vad pengarna ska användas till kommer Sida att säkerställa att insatsen inte används till andra ändamål. Sida kommer att genom hel och halvårsrapporter bli uppdaterade om hur Root Capitals valutakonto hanteras samt hur många nya lån som skyddas av kontot. Genom att New Island Capital gör sin analys av Root Capital och deras valutaexponering säkerställer Sida att det finns ett behov, hur stort det är och att valutrisken uppskattas. New Island Capital kommer också att kunna bidra till att öka Root Capitals interna kapacitet inom området. Det finns även utrymme at kunna exportera den kunskapen till lokala mindre banker. Genom avtalets utformning och New Island Capitals deltagande så bedömer Sida att risker omhändertas. Risk för bristande intern kapacitet, kontroll och styrning hos Root Capital anser Sida vara mycket liten, då de har en tydlig organisation och en bra intern och extern kontrollmiljö.

Root Capital (U.S. NGO) will to lend capital to small holders in Africa. RC balance sheet is in U.S. dollars and loans will be given in local currency. As loans are repaid, a foreign exchange loss is at risk for RC. To hedge the loans is difficult and expensive. An expense that small holders cannot take. Sida supports RC through a development loan to build up a currency reserve account

description.narrative: According to the agreement, if after five years and repayment of the New Island Loan there still are funds available in the FCRA, Root Capital will have free right to use them in their lending operations and the funds will be considered used and the agreement will terminate. The agreement has now ended. In 2015 there was a significant appreciation of the USD. In efforts to manage the level of the reserve in line with projections over the 5 year period, and with the ability to access hedges on 75% of Ghanaian Cedi and Tanzanian Schilling last year, Root Capital decided not to apply any additional loans to the reserve for the second half of 2015. After the initial exceptional situation the development of the lending and utilisation of the reserve has been continuous. Of the initial 5 MSEK approximately 2.8 MSEK (314, 419 USD). This, however, also includes interest premiums which has been added to the reserves. At times the premiums has added a positive net contribution to the reserves and together with the, perhaps narrow, focus on Sub-Saharan currencies has resulted in a relatively large portion of the initial contribution still remains after the five years of the agreement. Obviously, it would have been impossible to know beforehand what significant currency movements could be and how this will affect lending in Sub-Saharan countries specifically. In hindsight, added flexibility towards other currencies might have added such that the available funds woudl have been fully utilised within the agreement period. Nevertheless, the impression is that Root Capital has managed the funds in a correct and professional way and that, when used, the funds have had a positive impact.
